awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Computational Design of Metal-Organic Framework Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research in computational methods for the automatic exploration of the search space of metal-organic frameworks to obtain desired combinations of mechanical, thermal and chemical properties. A metal-organic framework is a repeating three-dimensional crystal lattice with a large open space-frame structure composed of organic linking molecules bonded to inorganic nodal units. The interconnected pore-spaces in these materials endow them with a rich variety of unusual properties that can be exploited for gas storage, gas separation, and catalysis. Given the constraints of chemical bonds and bond angles, one cannot easily customize the lattice for a particular size and shape. Thankfully there is an astronomically large number of permutations for combining various atomic elements together. However, human designers are confounded on how to find one for their particular problem domain. What is needed is a computational process to search the space for a best solution. By formalizing the molecular design as a decision tree, the developed computer algorithms will invent new materials whose functional behavior is defined by its chemical makeup and the resulting geometry and movement of the lattice structure. As part of testing the design approach, the project will address two technologically important problems:  designing new metal organic frameworks optimized for gas storage, and materials for separating isomers in industrially important chemical feed stocks. STEM outreach activities to high school students and teachers will also be performed.

Specifically, the project seeks materials that exhibit highly chemically selective adsorption or permeability of gases through mechanisms that arise from chemical, steric, and vibrational behavior of the frameworks. The computational search for this incorporates a unique graph transformation approach that mimics correct stoichiometric reactions and leads to a large search tree that is amenable to recent advances in artificial intelligence planning algorithms. Furthermore, machine learning methods will establish a link between the structure and function of organic frameworks by leveraging data from complex molecular simulations. This will lead to more efficient search of the decision tree so that meaningful results can be obtained. Through detailed simulations of the resulting metal organic frameworks, the researchers will publish how their new materials can be used to tackle challenging problems in energy storage, high-tech manufacturing, and the creation of new sensitive sensor equipment.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to define molecules using artificial intelligence and machine-learning. Specifically, these molecules would serve as ?linkers? in a metal-organic frameworks. Metal-organic frameworks are a new class of materials that have a crystalline structure that could be used in many interesting applications like optics, gas storage and filtration, or as catalyst surfaces. The molecular configuration of these materials is based on a 3D tiling of metal ions and organic molecules that link them together. The connection between molecular level behaviors and macroscopic properties are difficult to determine with the current analytical and numerical tools. Fortunately, metal organic compounds have a straightforward correlation between these levels. Unfortunately, engineers and chemists lack the intuition to design these molecules. Thus, we sought to use artificial intelligence and machine learning to define these for given applications.

Currently, there are several exciting research attempts currently exploring the computational definition of new chemicals and materials ? most notably are the contributions in pharmaceuticals. The one unique aspect in this project was the use of context-sensitive graph grammars to define a decision tree. What this means is that the rules for building molecular compounds are manually encoded in if-then rules (see Figure 1). Since such rules are well-known, it is sensible to define these in advance as opposed to using machine-learning to recreate the valid ways that atoms can bound together. For example, the rules related to single-, double- and aromatic-bonds, and the various atomic elements that can be combined. This is done while being careful not to create unstable or highly volatile compounds.

Monte-Carlo Tree-Search (MCTS) was used to search the tree created by the grammar rules for new linker molecules that met user-specified goals, such as target surface area, or the dimensions of the bounding cylinder (where the carboxyl connections are the ends of the cylinder). The values for these were defined to create metal-organic frameworks used for xenon-krypton separation. Resulting optimal linkers are shown in Figure 2.

One of the most meaningful observations in this research was a new understanding of Monte-Carlo Tree Search in design problems. The concept of ?roll-out? in MCTS is the act of looking ahead in the search tree to determine if the current option is worthy of pursuing. In the conventional use of MCTS in turn-based strategy games (like chess or Go), this roll-out ensues until the game ends in a win or a loss. But for design problems ? like the creation of a molecule, it is unclear how many future moves one should look-ahead. It doesn?t make sense to look forward so many steps that one creates a larger than needed molecule. A study at the end of the project, investigated the amount of look-ahead (see Figure 3). This initial result seems to show that too much look-ahead (8 or 9 steps) or too little look-ahead (1 to 3 steps) leads to poor solutions. This needs to be investigated more in the future. But the implications of understanding this could be used to affect future uses of AI in complex scientific and engineering design problems.

 


Last Modified: 12/23/2022
Modified by: Matthew I Campbell

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 3: An experiment where the number of look-ahead steps in MCTS is altered. Initial data seems to suggest that too much or too little look-ahead leads to poor solutions.
    MICampbell
    Copyrighted
    Matthew I Campbell
    Figure 3: An experiment of the number of look-ahead steps in MCTS
  • Figure 1: Simple rules for building organic linkers are defined by hand based on well-known chemical bonding. These individual rules define the transitions in an AI search tree, which is thus limited to only the valid chemical compounds.
    MICampbell
    Copyrighted
    Matthew I Campbell
    Figure 1: Simple rules for building organic linkers
  • Figure 2: Two Example Organic Linkers for Metal-Organic Frameworks that were computationally designed for a) optimal pose diameter, b) for optimal surface area.
    MICampbell
    Copyrighted
    Matthew I Campbell
    Figure 2: Two Example Organic Linkers for Metal-Organic Frameworks
